reviewText:
I would like to recommend that you read both the negative and positive reviews and make up your own mind before dismissing the game. I was initially in the negative, but have recently changed my mind after a few more hours offline (I have probably played closer to 5 hours)

You may ask what changed my mind, well after updating my AMD drivers and replacing a power cable for my HDD I haven't experienced  the same jerkiness and slowness that I was having before even when everything is set to low.

It's amazing, even though everything else was working fine, something as simple as a power cable and a driver update can make a lot of difference.

Update : I had to roll back to 15.11 drivers as the Crimson drivers were causing micro shuttering due to a downclock issue with the driver. The issue has been acknowledged by AMD so wait for a fix

However I must warn any potential purchaser and start with

Negatives :

The game still has some performance issues, but I have found these only occur in the following situations, with the following results and don't impact too negatively on the overall experience.

1. When there are a number of NPCs and you are in a town, bar etc, the frame rate can vary between a buttery smooth 60 and drop to as low as 30 in the first town. In the second town it drops to around 25.

These drops occur in all towns but are usually outside of combat situations, and are noticable but don't impact the game too much.

2. Ship battles drop below 60 to about 48FPS.

*Regardless of rig or graphical settings these issues have been occurring for people. While some people don't think this is an issue, I'm in the camp where I would much prefer 60 but because the game is no longer jerky and laggy that I can get past these.

3. A few bugs

I had an issue when my saves were taking a while to load, and then it crashed. After reloading it worked fine and fixed my issue I had with the save (I couldn't walk out of the bar, was hovering in mid air and textures were taking a while to load.

The rollback to 15.11 fixed the textures issue, and after the crash, the save fixed itself.

If you can get past the negatives then your in for an awesome game.

Pros :

Supports 21:9 native - as an owner of an ultrawide it is awesome to be able to play a game without having to do some modifications. The HUD and the game scales correctly to the screen without any issues. In game cutscenes are 21:9 native, the FMVs are 16/9 with black bars.

The map is 16:9 with black bars, and the inventory screen is also 16/9 with black bars.

The combat system with ships is fairly simple, but fun. There are 3 different types of cannon balls depending on the damage you want to do and ship battles feel fun and fluid.

The swordplay is awesome, but does take a bit of getting used to. If your expecting to press attack and just win, well your in for a bad time. You have your basic attack with mouse 1 and block with mouse 2, dodge with space, power attack with E and a special finishing move you can unleash.

The combat actually requires skill and timing and this can be brutal but I believe fair. Once you work out how to play the game, it is a lot more fun then say the witcher 2 sword combat which is mash the attack button to win.

Mixed :

While I like the dialogue as it is cheesy and campy, this may not be to everyone's taste.

There are a few times where sentences tend to roll into one another, or the dialogue inflection isn't quite on point for the dialogue being spoken. There's also a couple of times where I have clicked next to advance the dialogue, but only the next line of text comes up and you have to wait for the dialogue to finish.

It reminds me in a way of the Witcher 1 dialogue in that it kinda feels like that it was written for another language and would sound better that way.

On a side note I tried German Audio and English Text - Awesome but the subs don't stay on screen long enough during a cutscene or a scene that automatically advances the spoken dialogue but it is in no way a dealbreaker.

There are also a few minor bugs but the dev team is working on them. Read the forums for more info.

To sum up :

I haven't got far enough with the rest of the game to rate the missions and the rest of the game so I will update as I go through.

I hope the devs don't take this the wrong way but with a bit more optimization, a bit more polish and a patch or two to fix bugs and QOL (Quality of Life) issues I would have no problem recommending it without any warnings.

As it is I am having fun, the game cops a lot of flak (some warranted, some not so) so I would suggest give it a shot, and if you don't like it refund it. You have nothing to lose.

reviewText:
I was really looking forward to Raven's Cry when it came out in January 2015, but after almost only terrible reviews explaining a game in alpha state, with missing dialouges, crashing, and very bad optimization I put the game on hold until it was fixed/patched by the developers.

There was much talk on the forums that the devs were only fooling their customers once more when they gave out the old game under a new name, and that nothing actually was changed. As I never played the old game before getting my free upgrade to Vendetta: Curse of Raven's Cry, I will only write about the new one.

The atmosphere is great, and take you right into a pirate themed RPG world. Great visuals, good voice acting (don't know why so many says otherwise?), and great music/soundtrack (A bit vulgar, but really great when done right).

I have only played 5 and a half hour when writing this, so will come back and edit this review if it changes through the game, but as of now I am really satisfied.

I haven't had one single problem with graphic settings, and no lagging actually, so can't comment on the others here that have had those problems.

My setup is i7 4770K @4.4gHz, 2 X 256 GB SSD's in RAID 0 (1000 mb/s), 16 GB RAM @2133mhz, and GTX 780 3-way SLI.

I have at least enjoyed myself until now, so as of right now I would like to reccomend this game.

reviewText:
In my opinion:

Pros:

-great pirate atmosphere: people singing shanties in the taverns, drunken sailors wandering around, seagulls sounds... I love it :)

-ships and sea battles. Here the game truly shines. Depending on the weather everything changes: sometimes in the fog you are fighting blind, in high seas it's difficult to aim etc. You hear the orders being given, sailors scream when the ship gets hit-it's quite realistic. And all this management stuff-officers, upgrades,different types of ammo-it's not only for show-all those things do matter. For example: once I was chased by a more powerful ship-I was able to escape because I damaged its sails. Another one: good gunmaster and some skill points will make your crew reload cannons almost twice as fast as your enemies, and sometimes one second means the difference between life and death.

-beautiful locations. It's winter here in Poland(no snow today, but it's cold)-and I feel like I was on vacation in the Caribbean :)

-Raven-the bird. Great idea. He can bring you things (I secretly freed a prisoner because the bird brought me the keys to the cell) and distract or attack your enemies. And he will help fill your budget ;)

-fighting system. It is difficult (I've stopped counting how many times I've died...)-but, once you learn to dodge and block and once you unlock kicks and hook-it becomes enjoyable.


Cons:

-bugs (some graphics issues, some bad lipsyncs, but no crashes in my case)-nothing a patch (or two...) won't fix.

-sometimes I find the voice acting and NPCs behavior strange: someone is talking in a friendly manner but he's flailing like he wants to hit me in the face.

-dice poker. I loved it in the Witcher. Here I don't. It looks weird.

Conclusion: Vendetta probably won't make it to the top 10 RPGs of all time-but if you like ships and pirates give it a try :) I did-and I don't regret this decision :)

reviewText:
The core of my recommendation
is the very detailed and challenging naval combat combined with RPG elements set in beautiful landscapes.
Developers have truly put much effort into the game which can be seen during the play through.
Already the first 18 hours of my overall playtime I have spent with exploration, sailing and trading.


The Environment
The ambience sounds in my opinion are overwhelming for example you wander into the wilderness and  can hear all sorts of wildlife inhabiting the jungles and shorelines, never let your guard down as one wild cat or a crocodile might be hiding close waiting for the right moment to take your life.
The cities crowded of people such as beggars asking for a coin, musicians singing and playing different kinds of instruments, and many more.

The game does not only feature different times of day but also nicely done weather effects harmonizing with the great background music.
The textures are detailed, different gloom, shadow effects and reflections appeal.
It depends on if you are capable of playing this game at maximum settings but personally I have to say that this game even looks great on lower settings.


Naval combat:
It is a very advanced combat system, dynamic and strategic at the same time and that is why I explain my experience in more detail:

You start with a small schooner but later you can obtain different ship types.

Before you start your journey it is vital to keep a close eye on your ships stats.
The weight your ship can carry varies between type and the amount of crewmembers and cannon balls.
You have to make sure you do not overstock on ammo because you need space left for trading goods
You should not sink your enemies as the loot will be gone and you rather lose than make money.

Different types of shots are inflicting different damages such as destroying sails and masts, killing enemy crew members or destroying the ships broadside.
The damage done is visually impressive as you can see broken masts, fire on deck or holes. Furthermore the damage decreases movement or turning speed and if crewmembers die, the reloading time for cannons takes longer.

The boarding is very strategic and looks a bit turn based. You have the option to either continue using cannons damaging the vessel further or let your crew use their swords. After boarding is complete you have to decide which goods you take on board, if you have no space you can drop things you are currently not in need for.

Depending on what faction you attacked you just made some good friends while got on someone elseÂ´s shitlist

There are different types of crewmembers. The officers you can chose from have advantages and disadvantages.
Your first officer Donovan for example may proof not to be too efficient in boarding but is a great sailor as his men are able to improve your ships speed. You can hire your base crew in every harbor but of course they need to be paid and fed. If the morale is high the crew will make your life easier.

The changes you do to your ship by either upgrading it or equipping it with figureheads, sails and other things are not only changing it visually but also change the stats of it. You have to decide if you rather spend the time and invest a lot of money in your current vessel or obtain the next ship as soon as possible..

I love the AI in this game as the enemy acts intelligent


Man to man combat:
While I got used to naval combat fast, it takes me a lot of practice to master Chris's swordsmanship (opposed to gunnery).

It would have been nice if there had been a bigger tutorial mode.
At the beginning which had let you practice a bit more with the different types of weapons you can use and how to target the enemies.
However the quicksave function becomes very handy in here since you can save almost everywhere.
You also can heal yourself by using potions.

You have to be careful where to draw your sword or where you send your raven to steal as nearby people will attack you.
Getting surrounded leads you into serious trouble and results in a fast but painful death which makes it again very strategic as you have to pay close attention where and whom you fight.
Remember that sometimes it is wise to redraw for a moment rather than cut your way through because Chris is not a one man army.

I also have to mention that the AI here is again intelligent and will in fact be able to either protect himself and might give you a little support. The enemy currently needs to learn how to circle obstacles.

I enjoyed the idea a lot to include a raven into the battle system as it is a really cool ally for a pirate and his skills become very useful.

If you have a gamepad controls might be a bit easier compared to the keyboard.


Story

I will not say much about the story since I do not want to spoiler anything and it might depend on taste.
The story is not linear and it has several endings and a different progression is possible which adds plenty of replay value.
I enjoyed the character design and the voice cast.

Final words

There are a few bugs in game which I will write on a list and sent to the team but I am sure that the developers are going to fix them. Everyone can see that the staff is present if one visits the forum.
In my opinion the quest log needs some fine tuning as I sometimes have trouble to find out if a quest is in fact done or if there is still something left to do. The interface could be a bit prettier too.

Vendetta delivers a lot of fun and interaction no matter if you play story quests, side quests or join mini games such as dice games etc.
I already have 35 hours on my playtime but certainly I will make it 200 in the near future. I would also recommend this to every of my friends who is into the pirate theme and naval combat.
If you want to find out more about this game why not contact me or watch my broadcast?

reviewText:
Vendetta - Curse of Raven's Cry nails the pirate-adventure/action genre, as I hoped it would when Raven's Cry was first announced back in 2014.

I pre-ordered the deluxe edition of Raven's Cry over a year ago, having enjoyed Two Worlds II from the same developer and publisher. Reading about how buggy the game was on initial release, I decided to hold off on playing it pending the release of additional patches/bug-fixes promised by the developer. As it turns out, the developer made good on their word and released this updated version of the game, with a slightly different title.

I'm glad that the developers followed through with finishing the game and I'm also glad I waited to play this updated version, as it has turned out to be very enjoyable.

The updated Raven's Cry (this game) ended up coming out around the same time as Fallout 4, and costing about the same price. In my opinion, Raven's Cry is much more deserving of the 60-dollar price than Fallout 4. Whereas I found Fallout 4 to be unengaging and a regurgitation of its predecessors, I find Raven's Cry fun to play, with entertaining character conversations (actually, a lot of the writing is really intelligent and some - though not all - of the voice acting is really good) and a fun mix of naval combat and over-the-shoulder third-person gameplay.

This game, as I hoped it to be, is like a mix of Two Worlds II land-based action-RPG with Sid Meier's Pirates!-style navigation and ship-to-ship combat. It's fun.

Raven's Cry plays totally like Sea Dogs and it's sequels and spinoffs:
Sea Dogs (2000)
Pirates of the Caribbean (2003)
Age of Pirates: Caribbean Tales (2006)
Age of Pirates 2: City of Abandoned Ships (2009)

- superb music
- clunky groundcombat with horrible opponents AI ;)
- totally fun ship fights

Differences?
Unlike Sea Dogs and the rest, you can't improve" skills of your ship officers in Raven's Cry - skills they have by default never change.
